Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I gained a deeper understanding about the complexity of birds and how they function.
This course gives you a comprehensive overview of avian biology, and also exposes you to some of the groundbreaking work that Professor Prum is doing.

I knew birds were awesome before, but after this class, I know about so many cool functions of birds and specific birds who do crazy things. Definitely the kinds of things to drop on your friends and at cocktail parties. That said, I also know about the nitty-gritty biological things that were less scintillating to study, but given that this is an actual science class, it's pretty inevitable.
I learned about what makes birds unique - their feathers, evolution, anatomy, behavior, and social structures.
This class was awesome! I learned so much not just about birds, but dinosaurs, beauty, sexual selection, writing scientific review papers, and so much more. Loved it. Take it.
I learned a great deal about bird biology. I also learned how to research scientific literature and write a biology review paper.

I learned a lot about birds and was a bit surprised that this knowledge would translate very well to other organisms. I really enjoyed the section of the class where we talked about aesthetics. It was really satisfying to see aspects of humanities and STEM coming together.
amazing class. i learned a TON about avian biology and evolution.
I learned a whole lot about birds, especially feathers!

I could not possibly fit everything that I learned within this little box! Ornithology is such a rich subject because it combines chemistry, physics, biology, and as we learned at the end of the semester even art!
Learned so much amazing things about birds and their biology and so many new insights into biology and philosophy of science
Rick Prum knows the ins and outs of birds.

Learned a lot about general avian biology, including their evolution (birds are dinosaurs!), breeding systems, feathers, etc. You don't learn as much about individual groups of birds since that's for the lab, but you definitely go into the more general topics into significant depth.
An understanding of birds, in every area, and how they are important for human science
THis course was phenomenal.
We learned a little bit about basically everything related to birds. We did evolution from dinosaurs, anatomy, physiology, flight, sexual selection, beauty, etc.
I learned everything there is to know about birds! In a multidisciplinary approach, we learned about birds from beak to tail feather.

I learned so much about birds; Ornithology is not about memorizing hundreds of species, but it's about all birds themselves. The first half of the course talks a lot about the three big "evolutions" (the evolution of birds from dinosaurs, the evolution of feathers, and of flight); other lessons cover avian cognition, digestion, physiology, migration, sexual reproduction, and of course, the evolution of beauty.
My understanding of biological mechanisms improved. I learned how to write and properly format a research paper.

You'll learn a LOT about birds: evolution, feather development, flight, bird song, reproduction, etc. If you have any interest in biology, then I highly recommend taking the class. Prum is a fantastic lecturer, and he makes 3 9:25 classes per week at ESC worth the trek to.

I knew nothing about birds, and now I know more about birds than most people. I also learned how to write a scientific review paper, which I had never done before. Additionally, I learned a lot about how evolution is actually studied. Of course, I knew what evolution *was* but I'd never really interacted with it on an academic level before.

I learned A LOT about birds. Evolution, life systems, breeding, navigation, biology, migration, singing, and more. I learned why birds are important and what they have to teach us about larger questions like the origin of beauty and nature's position on sexual autonomy.
Lots and lots about birds! Also that I dont really wanna do science but thats a me thing.
I learned a lot about birds. Also how to read scientific papers and how write one.

I learned a LOT of interesting things about birds, and I think the nature of the class and the tests also helped me learn how to study for exams that have a lot of material with intricate details in a better way than I had previously been doing.
I learned a ton of interesting scientific information related to birds.
This course gave an expansive introduction to so many features of birds: evolution, song, migration, flight, beauty, and even more aspects.

I learnt a huge array of bird facts along with many general biology facts. It also touched on some interesting thoughts on the history of the science of evolution. It gave me an insight into how to write a scientific paper.

This course was an amazing course, truly eye-opening. My one critique is that there is not much opportunity for dialogue or questions; it's entirely and completely a lecture course. This can, I found, get a little grating. I wish there was more opportunity for discussion.

This course is highly engaging - the professor clearly enjoys his field of study and loves teaching it. All of the material is supposedly from his slides, but his slides are rather bad - I would prefer to have a well-written study guide instead.

Strengths: Prum is an awesome lecturer, and the class is just super interesting!
Weaknesses: I wish it wasn't at 9:25 :(

Strengths: Professor Prum is unbelievably knowledgable and a fantastic lecturer. He is very engaging.

Weaknesses: There was very little guidance for the term paper, which made writing it difficult, especially for non-biology majors. Professor Prum also blew through topics during lecture, making it difficult to really process and understand things. Additionally, the grading system for the lecture exams was harsh, and I did not receive much substantive feedback.
Professor Prum was always a bit behind the syllabus, which was fine because I learned a lot but he had to cut out a lot of material which was unfortunate.
the professor is amazing. very knowledgeable and passionate about his work and teaching.

Great lecturer, very interesting material. Some more guidance on what to study for the exams would have been helpful; the TAs also occasionally took points off on exams and didn't say why, which was really annoying.

Professor Prum is an excellent lecturer. The class covered a lot of material, but I never felt like we were skimming over things. I think it could be improved by making the lab class size larger and perhaps providing more external support for studying/paper writing via TAs. But overall a really solid course. I am not a science oriented person at all, and I found it easy to get up and go to class at 9:25 because it was so fascinating and fun!
THIS CLASS IS NOT A GUT. Great + engaging lectures, but tests are really hard and somewhat unfair -- and the whole class is three exams and a paper.
Lectures are amazing and super engaging and the course material is so well organised

The lectures for this course are amazing! Professor Prum is truly an expert in his field, and it was incredible to learn about aesthetic evolution, sexual autonomy, and other topics that Prum has actually pioneered in ornithology.
It will blow your mind. But he doesnt explain everything near the end - becomes kind of rushed. Could include some debate

Strengths: Extremely engaging lectures, the content is easy to understand, Professor Prum is really open to giving you feedback and advice on the final paper, oppotunities to go on birdwatching trips.

Strengths: information, teaching

Weaknesses: slides should be posted earlier - it is hard to follow all the info by ear alone in class
Only strengths
The lectures are very interesting, but the requirements for the term paper were not very clear and support was lacking.

This course is amazingly well crafted and taught.  The multidisciplinary approach was the strength of the course in addition to Prof. Prums lecturing.  He was very engaging and enthusiastic.  The only improvement might be a little more interaction with the TA.

This class covers so much about birds, and that's very important. I see birds in a new light, now that I know what's going on inside and outside of them. The class doesn't cover specific birds (if you want more of that, take the lab), but focusing on the general topics, which is very important and useful.

I think a study guide of list of terms and topics before each midterm/exam would be helpful to review the content.

I wishes that there were texts associated with the lecture, so that we were not directly dependent on the lectures. The lectures were excellent, but I find it difficult to learn if I don't have some level of freedom over the material.

Strengths: Prum, papa bird himself. He is an amazing lecturer with a great sense of humor. There were no readings for the class, but just by listening to Prum and taking good notes, I felt that I could get a solid grasp of the material. Prum also teaches us about his own insights into biology and more, which is fascinating in itself. Weaknesses: tests are fairly detail-heavy. You'll have to study a week in advance and go over all lectures + notes. But it's very doable, and there's always extra credit questions.
The lectures are amazing; the paper requirements were not clearly defined so they led to some frustration.

There are many strengths to this course. Professor Prum's lectures are informative and highly engaging, the course material is fascinating, and the exams were very fair. I don't think anything needs to be improved.
Would have appreciated structured review sessions prior to exams

The course is a classic lecture and has the strengths and weaknesses that one might expect. Professor Prum is very engaging and I always found his lectures fascinating. I think the course does not require any changes.
Incredible lectures! Early time slot is awful though.
This course was great.
I thought the lectures were really engaging, but I think that there are actually too few components of one's grade in this class, which can be pretty anxiety inducing.
This course's material was highly interesting and engaging. The grade rested strongly on relatively few tests and one paper, though I do not see a clear way around this.

The course requires a lot of commitment to memorizing content because the test can and will cover the broadest of themes to the most specific details. If you are able to commit that time to learning the content though, you're sure to get a lot out of the course.
It is a hgely interesting topic with great content. The paper was very stressful and it was a lot of memorisation.

Yes I would recommend this course to another student. It is heavy memorization but if you attend the lectures, Professor Prum is a great lecturer who is engaging and allows you to develop the same enthusiasm for the subject. I took this course as my EEB elective and it was a great decision.
I would definitely recommend this course to science majors and non-majors alike. It is a really eye-opening course, and radically changed my perception of birds and the natural world as a whole.

Yes, if you want to realize in-depth why birds are super friccin cool. That said, all the reviews say this, but despite the lack of week-to-week work, you will play yourself if you don't take the midterms seriously and/or don't go to lecture. Studying with a friend helps a lot, since the information comes at you really quickly in class and you might not have had time to jot everything down, and he doesn't really give a chance to go over the information again. The term paper can also catch you off-guard if you don't have very much or confidence experience with science writing.

This is one of the best courses I have taken here. It is well taught; the material and the professor are very engaging. This course is Not A Gut. The exams are easy to get partial credit on and hard to get full credit on. You will learn a lot and you will spend a lot of time and effort on this class.

Yes. The class definitely involves a fair bit of memorization for exams. It may seem like a gut, but it's actually pretty easy to do poorly, so watch out. It's very worth it though. Prum is an incredibly ornithologist -- when will you have an opportunity like this again??
I would recommend this course to students who are interested in birds. I would not recommend it to non-majors or people looking for a user-friendly science course.
This is one of the best classes I've taken at Yale. Birds are beautiful. Professor Prum is great. This is both a fun and interesting class.
yes, if they want to learn about birds!
Highly recommend - it's a great class, even if you know nothing about birds.
Yes absolutely! Take this course!

This course is one that I wish everyone could take. Changed my life and made me love birds so much more and think about science in so many new ways. Professor Prum is also an amazing guy and such a fun lecturer.
Yes! If you are interested in birds at all (or even if you're not), take this course! I left this class with a newfound appreciation for birds and learned so much about the biology of birds.
Yes it gives you a new perspective on knowledge and the natural world

Absolutely, I took this class having no previous knowledge or interest of birds and it ended up being one of the most interesting classes I've ever taken at Yale. Professor Prum is an excellent lecturer and definitely makes the morning walk up to ESC worth it. It seems like a lot of work with 3 exams and a paper, but the material is honestly not that hard (also very interdisciplinary if that's your thing: some physics, chemistry, even aesthetic philosophy to the very end), and the final is the same length as the midterm (with a lot more time to finish), and the grade distribution is very generous. Probably the hardest part is the final paper, but Prum gives a nice, flexible page range as well as a lot of advice on how to do it. This class is definitely one of Yale's gems and I'd recommend any student, STEM or not, to take it.
Perhaps, but only if they are willing to take very copious notes during each lecture
Absolutely
Yes, Professor Prum is a fantastic lecturer!

YES. TAKE THIS CLASS. TAKE THIS CLASS EVEN IF YOURE NOT INTERESTED IN BIRDS. professor prum is a god and you WILL be swayed by his clear knowledge about and enthusiasm for the subject. best class ive taken at yale.
I would honestly recommend that you Credit-D this class - it's super interesting, but the grading can be tough.
Absolutely take this course.  It is incredibly interesting, even if youre not a STEM student per say.

This class has truly been one of my favorite that I've ever taken at Yale. When I was bluebooking and came upon this class, I read a course evaluation calling Richard Prum a "bird god," and he truly is. His knowledge of the field and passion for the subject comes through in his teaching, making the class fun, insightful, and overall fascinating. Even if you never had much interest in birds before (I didn't), you'll really enjoy this class, as it opens up a new world of interesting information!
I would. The lextures are excellent, the material is interesting. Professor Prum is very committed.

Absolutely! This is by far one of my favorite classes at Yale. The material is fascinating, and I learned about an entire new area of biology. Later on, Prum delves into his theories of sexual selection & aesthetic revolution (and duck penises), which is really interesting too.
Yes, one of my favorite classes!

TAKE ORNITHOLOGY! I'm a senior non-science, and this is the best course I have ever taken at Yale. It couldn't be better. Professor Prum is highly engaging and knows EVERYTHING about birds. Birds are INCREDIBLE. They learn their songs in their dreams. And feathers are TOTALLY TUBULAR. You will learn so many incredible things about so many incredible birds. I think I might have to become an ornithologist now.

This class fulfilled my second science distributional credit and it was a good choice for me since I enjoy E&EB. I would recommend this class to other non-science majors like myself who are looking for a healthy challenge instead of just a gut science credit. Professor Prum is very engaging and lecture was always interesting.

Take the course if you are interested in (or have ever been interested in) birds. When I was a kid I was fascinated by birds and convinced my parents to take us bird-watching, and we got a bird feeder as well. This interest faded somewhat but was reignited and deepened by this class, which taught me more about birds than I ever expected to learn. It's a great lecture and the workload is very manageable.
Yes.
This course is amazing! Prum is a treasure and he loves birds so much that by the end of the course you will love them too.

I would recommend this class if you're looking for a challenging yet really interesting science class, you think birds are cool, you're willing to study a lot, and you're ok with memorization-based exams.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, because it was extremely interesting and taught by a world-class expert in the field. However, I would caution other students that the work load is not negligible.

I would recommend the course if you're looking for a much deeper look at birds beyond their names and songs, which is just the tip of the iceberg compared to this course. Every class is filled with fascinating aspects of birds and examples from around the world, and Professor Prum's excitement for it comes out in his lectures.
Yes you will be mind blown by the bird world!
